did.head: Collection Overview

repository.label: Location:
repository.corpname: Connecticut Polish American Archives, Elihu Burritt Library, Central Connecticut State University

did.abstract: The Polish American Historical Association (PAHA) was established in 1942 to promote the study of immigration of Poles to the United States. For the first presidents of the organization it was important to promote scholarly knowledge of Poles and Polish Americans, collect and preserve information on the topic, and elevate historical research. PAHA attracted many scholars, secular and clergy, in the fields of history and ethnic studies. The organization promoted their mission through publication of the Polish American Studies journal. The collection consists of material documenting history of the organization and its various activities. It includes correspondence material from annual meetings and conferences as well as membership and financial data.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: PAHA was initially a part of the Polish Institute of Arts and Science (PIASA), which was organized in 1942 with the financial help of the Polish government, by Polish scholars and scientists who found refuge in the United States. The PIASA first president, Prof. Oskar Halecki, recognized the importance of studying immigration of Poles to America. In 1942 the Commission for Research on Polish Immigration was established and was led by Miecislaus Haiman, a published historian of Polonia. In 1944 the Commission became an independent organization devoted to the study and research of history of Polish Americans, and in 1948 adopted its current name - Polish American Historical Association.

Prof. Haiman realized how important it was to bring scholarly knowledge of Polish Americans to main stream history of America well before the movement of ethnic studies in late 1960's. Haiman’s priorities were raising the standards of historical research, advocating the importance of data collection and preservation and creating the proper archives for collected material. This agenda was upheld by Rev. Jospeh Swastek who was PAHA's second president. Among early members of PAHA there were many Catholic priests and nuns. Clergy played a very important role for immigrants and the church was the main institution that served spiritual needs as well as social and educational needs. For many immigrants, to become a priest or nun was a way to be educated. Later, second and third generations of Polish Americans interested in their own roots joined PAHA. They established several Polish Studies programs at American universities, pursued research projects related to Polish Americans and cooperated with scholars from Poland who were interested in the history of Polonia [as the Polish American community calls itself]. As a result of such interest a first joint conference was held in Krakow, Poland in 1986. In June of 2004 PAHA held their international conference at Central Connecticut State University in celebration of "150 years of Polonia in North America." Since 1944 PAHA has been publishing Polish American Studies, a journal which serves as a forum for scholars to share their research. It includes reviews, bibliographies, criticisms and information on future publications. PAHA publishes a quarterly newsletter for its members and organizes annual conferences, which take place during annual meetings of the American Historical Association (AHA), of which PAHA is an affiliate. PAHA funds some scholarly publications and gives several awards. The Haiman Award is for sustained effort in the area of Polish American Studies, the Halecki Prize is for the best book related to Polish American topic and the Swastek Prize is for the best scholarly article in Polish American Studies journal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p: The PAHA archives consist of material related to establishing of the association, their constitution and by-laws and amendments. It includes material from conferences, executive directors' meetings and extensive correspondence with well known scholars in the field. Material includes information on membership, finances, various publications and extensive collection of clippings and documentation for various projects. The collection is chiefly in English with very small percentage of material in the Polish language.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Cite as: Polish American Historical Association (PAHA) records (CPAA 05-11). Connecticut Polish American Archives, Central Connecticut State University, New Britain.

acqinfo.p: The PAHA archives were donated in 2005. Parts of the records were sent by presidents of the organization and periodicaly are sent by the executive secretary.

processinfo.p: Material in the collection was processed by Renata Vickrey.

list.item: For related material see the following collections:

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material in the collection is arranged in series. Folders within each series are in subject and chronological order. Boxes 8 and 9 contain correspondence and other related material compiled and bound by Walter Lasinski, Treasurer of PAHA for 1989-1992. The material is preserved in the form it was received, some items in the bound volumes might be duplicates of material already in the collection.

dsc.p: [The following section contains a detailed listing of the materials in the collection.]
